lines.content: This is a project template for a greenfield Java project. It's named after the Java mascot _Duke_. Given below are instructions on how to use it.
Prerequisites: JDK 11, update Intellij to the most recent version.
1. Open Intellij (if you are not in the welcome screen, click `File` > `Close Project` to close the existing project first)
1. Open the project into Intellij as follows:
1. Select the project directory, and click `OK`.
1. If there are any further prompts, accept the defaults.
1. Configure the project to use **JDK 11** (not other versions) as explained in [here](https://www.jetbrains.com/help/idea/sdk.html#set-up-jdk).
In the same dialog, set the **Project language level** field to the `SDK default` option.

3. After that, locate the `src/main/java/duke.Duke.java` file, right-click it, and choose `Run duke.Duke.main()` (if the code editor is showing compile errors, try restarting the IDE). If the setup is correct, you should see something like the below as the output:
* Enumerates the various command types that the Duke application can recognize and process.
* Each enumeration value corresponds to a specific command that the user can issue to interact with
/** Command to add a new 'ToDo' task. */
/** Command to add a new 'Deadline' task. */
/** Command to add a new 'Event' task. */
/** Command to mark a task as done. */
/** Command to unmark a previously marked task. */
/** Command to list all tasks on a specified date. */
/** Command type when the input command is not recognized. */
* Main class for the Duke application.
* The Duke application is a task management application that allows users to manage and track
* tasks such as todos, deadlines, and events. It provides a command-line interface for users
/** Task list to store and manage all tasks. */

/** User interface object for interacting with the user. */

/** Storage object for saving and loading tasks to/from a file. */
private static final Storage storage = new Storage(ui);

* This method listens for user inputs, parses the commands, processes them,
* and provides appropriate responses. It handles task creation, modification,
* deletion, listing, and other related operations.

throw new DukeException("duke.task.Event format is incorrect.");

assertEquals("T | 0 | test1", test1.toFileString(), "toFileString an uncompleted task.");
assertEquals("T | 1 | test2", test2.toFileString(), "toFileString a completed task.");
assertEquals("[T][ ] test1", test1.toString(), "String of an uncompleted task.");
assertEquals("[T][X] test2", test2.toString(), "String of a completed task.");
